segment.source: 4771(F) Kerberos pre-authentication failed.
segment.target: 4771(F) Kerberos pre-authentication failed.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4771(F) Kerberos pre-authentication failed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4771(F) Kerberos pre-authentication failed.

segment.source: 4771(F): Kerberos pre-authentication failed.
segment.target: 4771(F): Kerberos pre-authentication failed.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time the Key Distribution Center fails to issue a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT).
segment.target: This event generates every time the Key Distribution Center fails to issue a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT).

segment.source: This can occur when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart card authentication (for example, with a “Domain Controller” or “Domain Controller Authentication” template), the user’s password has expired, or the wrong password was provided.
segment.target: This can occur when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart card authentication (for example, with a “Domain Controller” or “Domain Controller Authentication” template), the user’s password has expired, or the wrong password was provided.

segment.source: This event generates only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This event generates only on domain controllers.

segment.source: This event is not generated if “Do not require Kerberos preauthentication” option is set for the account.
segment.target: This event is not generated if “Do not require Kerberos preauthentication” option is set for the account.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Account Information:
segment.target: Account Information:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account object for which (TGT) ticket was requested.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account object for which (TGT) ticket was requested.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: For example: CONTOSOdadmin or CONTOSOWIN81$.
segment.target: For example: CONTOSOdadmin or CONTOSOWIN81$.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name: Type = UnicodeString: the name of account, for which (TGT) ticket was requested.
segment.target: Account Name: Type = UnicodeString: the name of account, for which (TGT) ticket was requested.

segment.source: Computer account name ends with character.
segment.target: Computer account name ends with character.

segment.source: User account example: dadmin
segment.target: User account example: dadmin

segment.source: Computer account example: WIN81$
segment.target: Computer account example: WIN81$

segment.source: Service Information:
segment.target: Service Information:

segment.source: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the service in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.
segment.target: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the service in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.

segment.source: Typically has one of the following formats:
segment.target: Typically has one of the following formats:

segment.source: krbtgt/DOMAINNETBIOSNAME.
segment.target: krbtgt/DOMAINNETBIOSNAME.

segment.source: Example: krbtgt/CONTOSO
segment.target: Example: krbtgt/CONTOSO

segment.source: krbtgt/DOMAINFULLNAME.
segment.target: krbtgt/DOMAINFULLNAME.

segment.source: Example: krbtgt/CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Example: krbtgt/CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: Network Information:
segment.target: Network Information:

segment.source: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the TGT request was received.
segment.target: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the TGT request was received.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: IPv6 or IPv4 address.
segment.target: IPv6 or IPv4 address.

segment.source: ::ffff:IPv4address.
segment.target: ::ffff:IPv4address.

segment.source: ::1 - localhost.
segment.target: ::1 - localhost.

segment.source: Client Port Type = UnicodeString: source port number of client network connection (TGT request connection).
segment.target: Client Port Type = UnicodeString: source port number of client network connection (TGT request connection).

segment.source: 0 for local (localhost) requests.
segment.target: 0 for local (localhost) requests.

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Ticket Options: Type = HexInt32: this is a set of different Ticket Flags in hexadecimal format.
segment.target: Ticket Options: Type = HexInt32: this is a set of different Ticket Flags in hexadecimal format.

segment.source: Example:
segment.target: Example:

segment.source: Ticket Options: 0x40810010
segment.target: Ticket Options: 0x40810010

segment.source: Using MSB 0 bit numbering we have bit 1, 8, 15 and 27 set = Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok.
segment.target: Using MSB 0 bit numbering we have bit 1, 8, 15 and 27 set = Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok.

segment.source: Note In the table below “MSB 0” bit numbering is used, because RFC documents use this style.
segment.target: Note In the table below “MSB 0” bit numbering is used, because RFC documents use this style.

segment.source: In “MSB 0” style bit numbering begins from left.
segment.target: In “MSB 0” style bit numbering begins from left.

segment.source: The most common values:
segment.target: The most common values:

segment.source: 0x40810010 - Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok
segment.target: 0x40810010 - Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok

segment.source: 0x40810000 - Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize
segment.target: 0x40810000 - Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize

segment.source: 0x60810010 - Forwardable, Forwarded, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok
segment.target: 0x60810010 - Forwardable, Forwarded, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok

segment.source: Bit
segment.target: Bit

segment.source: Flag Name
segment.target: Flag Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Reserved
segment.target: Reserved

segment.source: Forwardable
segment.target: Forwardable

segment.source: (TGT only).
segment.target: (TGT only).

segment.source: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue a new TGT—based on the presented TGT—with a different network address based on the presented TGT.
segment.target: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue a new TGT—based on the presented TGT—with a different network address based on the presented TGT.

segment.source: Forwarded
segment.target: Forwarded

segment.source: Indicates either that a TGT has been forwarded or that a ticket was issued from a forwarded TGT.
segment.target: Indicates either that a TGT has been forwarded or that a ticket was issued from a forwarded TGT.

segment.source: Proxiable
segment.target: Proxiable

segment.source: (TGT only).
segment.target: (TGT only).

segment.source: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue tickets with a network address that differs from the one in the TGT.
segment.target: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue tickets with a network address that differs from the one in the TGT.

segment.source: Proxy
segment.target: Proxy

segment.source: Indicates that the network address in the ticket is different from the one in the TGT used to obtain the ticket.
segment.target: Indicates that the network address in the ticket is different from the one in the TGT used to obtain the ticket.

segment.source: Allow-postdate
segment.target: Allow-postdate

segment.source: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).
segment.target: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).

segment.source: Postdated
segment.target: Postdated

segment.source: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).
segment.target: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).

segment.source: Invalid
segment.target: Invalid

segment.source: This flag indicates that a ticket is invalid, and it must be validated by the KDC before use.
segment.target: This flag indicates that a ticket is invalid, and it must be validated by the KDC before use.

segment.source: Application servers must reject tickets which have this flag set.
segment.target: Application servers must reject tickets which have this flag set.

segment.source: Renewable
segment.target: Renewable

segment.source: Used in combination with the End Time and Renew Till fields to cause tickets with long life spans to be renewed at the KDC periodically.
segment.target: Used in combination with the End Time and Renew Till fields to cause tickets with long life spans to be renewed at the KDC periodically.

segment.source: Initial
segment.target: Initial

segment.source: Indicates that a ticket was issued using the authentication service (AS) exchange and not issued based on a TGT.
segment.target: Indicates that a ticket was issued using the authentication service (AS) exchange and not issued based on a TGT.

segment.source: Pre-authent
segment.target: Pre-authent

segment.source: Indicates that the client was authenticated by the KDC before a ticket was issued.
segment.target: Indicates that the client was authenticated by the KDC before a ticket was issued.

segment.source: This flag usually indicates the presence of an authenticator in the ticket.
segment.target: This flag usually indicates the presence of an authenticator in the ticket.

segment.source: It can also flag the presence of credentials taken from a smart card logon.
segment.target: It can also flag the presence of credentials taken from a smart card logon.

segment.source: Opt-hardware-auth
segment.target: Opt-hardware-auth

segment.source: This flag was originally intended to indicate that hardware-supported authentication was used during pre-authentication.
segment.target: This flag was originally intended to indicate that hardware-supported authentication was used during pre-authentication.

segment.source: This flag is no longer recommended in the Kerberos V5 protocol.
segment.target: This flag is no longer recommended in the Kerberos V5 protocol.

segment.source: KDCs MUST NOT issue a ticket with this flag set.
segment.target: KDCs MUST NOT issue a ticket with this flag set.

segment.source: KDCs SHOULD NOT preserve this flag if it is set by another KDC.
segment.target: KDCs SHOULD NOT preserve this flag if it is set by another KDC.

segment.source: Transited-policy-checked
segment.target: Transited-policy-checked

segment.source: KILE MUST NOT check for transited domains on servers or a KDC.
segment.target: KILE MUST NOT check for transited domains on servers or a KDC.

segment.source: Application servers MUST ignore the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag.
segment.target: Application servers MUST ignore the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag.

segment.source: Ok-as-delegate
segment.target: Ok-as-delegate

segment.source: The KDC MUST set the OK-AS-DELEGATE flag if the service account is trusted for delegation.
segment.target: The KDC MUST set the OK-AS-DELEGATE flag if the service account is trusted for delegation.

segment.source: Request-anonymous
segment.target: Request-anonymous

segment.source: KILE not use this flag.
segment.target: KILE not use this flag.

segment.source: Name-canonicalize
segment.target: Name-canonicalize

segment.source: In order to request referrals the Kerberos client MUST explicitly request the "canonicalize" KDC option for the AS-REQ or TGS-REQ.
segment.target: In order to request referrals the Kerberos client MUST explicitly request the "canonicalize" KDC option for the AS-REQ or TGS-REQ.

segment.source: Unused
segment.target: Unused

segment.source: Disable-transited-check
segment.target: Disable-transited-check

segment.source: By default the KDC will check the transited field of a TGT against the policy of the local realm before it will issue derivative tickets based on the TGT.
segment.target: By default the KDC will check the transited field of a TGT against the policy of the local realm before it will issue derivative tickets based on the TGT.

segment.source: If this flag is set in the request, checking of the transited field is disabled.
segment.target: If this flag is set in the request, checking of the transited field is disabled.

segment.source: Tickets issued without the performance of this check will be noted by the reset (0) value of the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag, indicating to the application server that the transited field must be checked locally.
segment.target: Tickets issued without the performance of this check will be noted by the reset (0) value of the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag, indicating to the application server that the transited field must be checked locally.

segment.source: KDCs are encouraged but not required to honor
segment.target: KDCs are encouraged but not required to honor

segment.source: the DISABLE-TRANSITED-CHECK option.
segment.target: the DISABLE-TRANSITED-CHECK option.

segment.source: Should not be in use, because Transited-policy-checked flag is not supported by KILE.
segment.target: Should not be in use, because Transited-policy-checked flag is not supported by KILE.

segment.source: Renewable-ok
segment.target: Renewable-ok

segment.source: The RENEWABLE-OK option indicates that a renewable ticket will be acceptable if a ticket with the requested life cannot otherwise be provided, in which case a renewable ticket may be issued with a renew-till equal to the requested end time.
segment.target: The RENEWABLE-OK option indicates that a renewable ticket will be acceptable if a ticket with the requested life cannot otherwise be provided, in which case a renewable ticket may be issued with a renew-till equal to the requested end time.

segment.source: The value of the renew-till field may still be limited by local limits, or limits selected by the individual principal or server.
segment.target: The value of the renew-till field may still be limited by local limits, or limits selected by the individual principal or server.

segment.source: Enc-tkt-in-skey
segment.target: Enc-tkt-in-skey

segment.source: No information.
segment.target: No information.

segment.source: Unused
segment.target: Unused

segment.source: Renew
segment.target: Renew

segment.source: The RENEW option indicates that the present request is for a renewal.
segment.target: The RENEW option indicates that the present request is for a renewal.

segment.source: The ticket provided is encrypted in the secret key for the server on which it is valid.
segment.target: The ticket provided is encrypted in the secret key for the server on which it is valid.

segment.source: This option will only be honored if the ticket to be renewed has its RENEWABLE flag set and if the time in its renew-till field has not passed.
segment.target: This option will only be honored if the ticket to be renewed has its RENEWABLE flag set and if the time in its renew-till field has not passed.

segment.source: The ticket to be renewed is passed in the padata field as part of the authentication header.
segment.target: The ticket to be renewed is passed in the padata field as part of the authentication header.

segment.source: Validate
segment.target: Validate

segment.source: This option is used only by the ticket-granting service.
segment.target: This option is used only by the ticket-granting service.

segment.source: The VALIDATE option indicates that the request is to validate a postdated ticket.
segment.target: The VALIDATE option indicates that the request is to validate a postdated ticket.

segment.source: Should not be in use, because postdated tickets are not supported by KILE.
segment.target: Should not be in use, because postdated tickets are not supported by KILE.

segment.source: Table 6.
segment.target: Table 6.

segment.source: Kerberos ticket flags.
segment.target: Kerberos ticket flags.

segment.source: Failure Code Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal failure code of failed TGT issue operation.
segment.target: Failure Code Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal failure code of failed TGT issue operation.

segment.source: The table below contains the list of the most common error codes for this event:
segment.target: The table below contains the list of the most common error codes for this event:

segment.source: Code
segment.target: Code

segment.source: Code Name
segment.target: Code Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Possible causes
segment.target: Possible causes

segment.source: KDCERRPADATATYPENOSUPP
segment.target: KDCERRPADATATYPENOSUPP

segment.source: KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)
segment.target: KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)

segment.source: Smart card logon is being attempted and the proper certificate cannot be located.
segment.target: Smart card logon is being attempted and the proper certificate cannot be located.

segment.source: This can happen because the wrong certification authority (CA) is being queried or the proper CA cannot be contacted in order to get Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication certificates for the domain controller.
segment.target: This can happen because the wrong certification authority (CA) is being queried or the proper CA cannot be contacted in order to get Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication certificates for the domain controller.

segment.source: It can also happen when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart cards (Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication templates).
segment.target: It can also happen when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart cards (Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication templates).

segment.source: KDCERRKEYEXPIRED
segment.target: KDCERRKEYEXPIRED

segment.source: Password has expired—change password to reset
segment.target: Password has expired—change password to reset

segment.source: The user’s password has expired.
segment.target: The user’s password has expired.

segment.source: KDCERRPREAUTHFAILED
segment.target: KDCERRPREAUTHFAILED

segment.source: Pre-authentication information was invalid
segment.target: Pre-authentication information was invalid

segment.source: The wrong password was provided.
segment.target: The wrong password was provided.

segment.source: Pre-Authentication Type Type = UnicodeString: the code of pre-Authentication type which was used in TGT request.
segment.target: Pre-Authentication Type Type = UnicodeString: the code of pre-Authentication type which was used in TGT request.

segment.source: Table 5.
segment.target: Table 5.

segment.source: Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Type
segment.target: Type

segment.source: Type Name
segment.target: Type Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Logon without Pre-Authentication.
segment.target: Logon without Pre-Authentication.

segment.source: PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP
segment.target: PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP

segment.source: This is a normal type for standard password authentication.
segment.target: This is a normal type for standard password authentication.

segment.source: PA-ETYPE-INFO
segment.target: PA-ETYPE-INFO

segment.source: The ETYPE-INFO pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.
segment.target: The ETYPE-INFO pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.

segment.source: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.
segment.target: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.

segment.source: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.

segment.source: PA-PK-AS-REPOLD
segment.target: PA-PK-AS-REPOLD

segment.source: Used for Smart Card logon authentication.
segment.target: Used for Smart Card logon authentication.

segment.source: PA-PK-AS-REP
segment.target: PA-PK-AS-REP

segment.source: This type should also be used for Smart Card authentication, but in certain Active Directory environments, it is never seen.
segment.target: This type should also be used for Smart Card authentication, but in certain Active Directory environments, it is never seen.

segment.source: PA-ETYPE-INFO2
segment.target: PA-ETYPE-INFO2

segment.source: The ETYPE-INFO2 pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.
segment.target: The ETYPE-INFO2 pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.

segment.source: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.
segment.target: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.

segment.source: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.

segment.source: PA-SVR-REFERRAL-INFO
segment.target: PA-SVR-REFERRAL-INFO

segment.source: Used in KDC Referrals tickets.
segment.target: Used in KDC Referrals tickets.

segment.source: PA-ENCRYPTED-CHALLENGE
segment.target: PA-ENCRYPTED-CHALLENGE

segment.source: Logon using Kerberos Armoring (FAST).
segment.target: Logon using Kerberos Armoring (FAST).

segment.source: Supported starting from Windows Server 2012 domain controllers and Windows 8 clients.
segment.target: Supported starting from Windows Server 2012 domain controllers and Windows 8 clients.

segment.source: This type shows in Audit Failure events.
segment.target: This type shows in Audit Failure events.

segment.source: Certificate Information:
segment.target: Certificate Information:

segment.source: Certificate Issuer Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of Certification Authority which issued smart card certificate.
segment.target: Certificate Issuer Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of Certification Authority which issued smart card certificate.

segment.source: Populated in Issued by field in certificate.
segment.target: Populated in Issued by field in certificate.

segment.source: Always empty for 4771 events.
segment.target: Always empty for 4771 events.

segment.source: Certificate Serial Number Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s serial number.
segment.target: Certificate Serial Number Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s serial number.

segment.source: Can be found in Serial number field in the certificate.
segment.target: Can be found in Serial number field in the certificate.

segment.source: Always empty for 4771 events.
segment.target: Always empty for 4771 events.

segment.source: Certificate Thumbprint Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s thumbprint.
segment.target: Certificate Thumbprint Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s thumbprint.

segment.source: Can be found in Thumbprint field in the certificate.
segment.target: Can be found in Thumbprint field in the certificate.

segment.source: Always empty for 4771 events.
segment.target: Always empty for 4771 events.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4771(F): Kerberos pre-authentication failed.
segment.target: For 4771(F): Kerberos pre-authentication failed.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “Security ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “Security ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Security ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Security ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “Security ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “Security ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Security ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Security ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: You can track all 4771 events where the Client Address is not from your internal IP range or not from private IP ranges.
segment.target: You can track all 4771 events where the Client Address is not from your internal IP range or not from private IP ranges.

segment.source: If you know that Account Name should be used only from known list of IP addresses, track all Client Address values for this Account Name in 4771 events.
segment.target: If you know that Account Name should be used only from known list of IP addresses, track all Client Address values for this Account Name in 4771 events.

segment.source: If Client Address is not from the whitelist, generate the alert.
segment.target: If Client Address is not from the whitelist, generate the alert.

segment.source: All Client Address = ::1 means local authentication.
segment.target: All Client Address = ::1 means local authentication.

segment.source: If you know the list of accounts which should log on to the domain controllers, then you need to monitor for all possible violations, where Client Address = ::1 and Account Name is not allowed to log on to any domain controller.
segment.target: If you know the list of accounts which should log on to the domain controllers, then you need to monitor for all possible violations, where Client Address = ::1 and Account Name is not allowed to log on to any domain controller.

segment.source: All 4771 events with Client Port field value 0 and 1024 should be examined, because a well-known port was used for outbound connection.
segment.target: All 4771 events with Client Port field value 0 and 1024 should be examined, because a well-known port was used for outbound connection.

segment.source: Also monitor the fields shown in the following table, to discover the issues listed:
segment.target: Also monitor the fields shown in the following table, to discover the issues listed:

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Issue to discover
segment.target: Issue to discover

segment.source: Pre-Authentication Type
segment.target: Pre-Authentication Type

segment.source: Value is not 15 when account must use a smart card for authentication.
segment.target: Value is not 15 when account must use a smart card for authentication.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Pre-Authentication Type
segment.target: Pre-Authentication Type

segment.source: Value is not 2 when only standard password authentication is in use in the organization.
segment.target: Value is not 2 when only standard password authentication is in use in the organization.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Pre-Authentication Type
segment.target: Pre-Authentication Type

segment.source: Value is not 138 when Kerberos Armoring is enabled for all Kerberos communications in the organization.
segment.target: Value is not 138 when Kerberos Armoring is enabled for all Kerberos communications in the organization.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Result Code
segment.target: Result Code

segment.source: 0x10 (KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)).
segment.target: 0x10 (KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)).

segment.source: This error can help you to more quickly identify smart-card related problems with Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: This error can help you to more quickly identify smart-card related problems with Kerberos authentication.

segment.source: Result Code
segment.target: Result Code

segment.source: 0x18 ((Pre-authentication information was invalid), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.
segment.target: 0x18 ((Pre-authentication information was invalid), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.

segment.source: This can be an indicator of brute-force attack on the account password, especially for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: This can be an indicator of brute-force attack on the account password, especially for highly critical accounts.
